div1.head: The State Historical Society of Missouri
div1.p: The State Historical Society of Missouri was organized to collect, preserve, make accessible and publish the history of Missouri.

Founded by the Missouri Press Association, the Society in 1899 was made "the trustee of this state" by the Fortieth General Assembly, and all its property is held in trust for the State of Missouri. Today the Society is a division of the State Department of Education.
The library and collections the Society has accumulated through the years are now worth more than the total amount of the state appropriations it has received.
Missourians boast one of the two largest state historical societies in the nation in number of active members.

The society maintains a reference and research library and historical art collections in Columbia; publishes historical studies, documentary works, and The Missouri Historical Review; and answers refer-
ence inquiries from the public. It promotes local history through the organization of county historical societies. The Society compiles and distributes the "This Week in Missouri History" series of illustrated feature articles as a free service to newspaper editors.

The Society's library contains tens of thousands of volumes of books, pamphlets, periodicals and reports pertaining to Missouri or written by Missourians, besides thousands of manuscripts and maps. It has become a research center for writers, students, and for individuals tracing genealogies.

Missouri newspapers from 1808 to present are preserved in bound volumes and on microfilm and photastats, with current papers from every Missouri county arriving weekly. A million pages of Missouri newspapers are microfilmed in a year.
The J. Christian Bay Collection is one of the most valuable in the field of Middle Western Americana either publicly or privately owned. It is housed in a special rare book room.
The Society has several notable historical art collections.

The Thomas Hart Benton Gallery of World War II paintings includes the Missouri artist's Year of Peril series, first used by the U. S. government in propaganda work, and the artist's gift, "The Negro Soldier."
Missouri's most famous historical painting, "Order No. 11" heads the George Caleb Bingham collection of eight 19th century portraits and genre paintings.
The Society owns the Daniel R. Fitzpatrick collection of 1,476 original drawings of cartoons made for the St. Louis Post-Dispatch.
A recent addition is a group of woodcuts and engravings by Fred Geary, many depicting Missouri scenes.

One of the Society's most important activities is publishing original historical material. Its magazine, The Missouri Historical Review, contains scholarly articles on our state history, interestingly presented and attractively illustrated, along with notes on current historical activities.

Other publications have been Missouri, Day by Day and Vance Randolph's nationally praised Ozark Folksongs in four volumes. Documentary publications include the Journal and Debates of Missouri's Constitutional Convention of 1875 (14 vols.), and the Messages of Missouri governors from 1820 to 1953 (17 vols.).

Annual membership in the State Historical Society of Missouri costs $1.00 a year and entitles you to attend the annual meeting and annual banquet of the society and to receive free of charge the quarterly Missouri Historical Review. Names of new members are recorded in each issue of the Review. Life membership for individuals is $20.
Your membership will bring you a lively new interest in your state and people. You'll enjoy fellowship with a group active in creating a state historical consciousness.

Come in to visit your State Historical Society when you are in Columbia. The Society is located in the University Library Building on Lowry Street. Hours are 8:00-12:00 and 1:25-5:00 on Monday through Friday and Saturday morning.

When writing address:
FLOYD C. SHOEMAKER, Secretary The State Historical Society of Missouri Columbia, Missouri
